channel.title: Using Reflection?
channel.description:
OK... so... like... you know how we get a field from a class by: (also heard sex w/ jagex works, anyone try it yet?) [code] Class FOOOL = DumbASs.class; Field SHITKTHNX = FOOOL.getDeclaredField("MY IP NOOB"); SHITKTHNX = SHITKTHNX.get(new DumbASs()); [/code]
mhhm. now that's sexy k. BUT how do we get the classes that were called by client.class? cause if we did... [code] loadClass like xo.j or sumthing [/code]
it wouldn't be the class that client.class called and is using, RIGHT?
if it's not HOW DO WE GET IT (ARHGJKDHJDFHJDF i just can't figure out)... on the other hand, am i even going in the right direction?
so. any jizz opinions?
[center][img]http://moparisthebest.com/smf/Themes/default/images/warnwarn.gif[/img] /b/ tard[/center]

item.title: Using Reflection?
item.dc:creator: @Nader_H.I.M Nader[H.I.M]
item.description:
@Nader_H.I.M wrote:

[quote=“qauters, post:24, topic:282217”][quote author=Nader[H.I.M] link=topic=372894.msg2871201#msg2871201 date=1247774542]
if you are working directly on the client , just get its classloader and reflect fields out of it ,
[/quote]
You have a terrible way of talking. If you are working directly on the client (which you most likely aren’t), you can get it’s classloader. Then use loadClass on it to find the required classes. Or you get a bit smarter and get all the loader classes directly from it (useful for reflection explorers)

[quote author=Nader[H.I.M] link=topic=372894.msg2871201#msg2871201 date=1247774542]
you were trying to use the Loader directly for a cached applet, just get the classLoader of the Canvas field located in the Loader.
[/quote]
Get the classloader of the applet field in the loader.

[quote author=Nader[H.I.M] link=topic=372894.msg2871201#msg2871201 date=1247774542]
Note: get(null) , gets the object incase it was static, else u replace the null by its premitive class.
[/quote]
get(null) indeed gets an object in case it was static, otherwise you have to replace ‘null’ by the object from which you want to reflect the field of! Not a primitive class.

Example:
Object client = loader.class.getField(“client”).get(loader);

int static_int = client.class.getField(“whatever”).getInt(null);
int normal_int = client.class.getField(“whatever”).getInt(client);[/quote]
Before you give your dumb advises just focus on your case, what the fuck is this?
int normal_int = client.class.getField(“whatever”).getInt(client);
Client’s Fields are all static you idiot ,hence this is the worst example you can give , and where is the promising Qbot2 that never appeared?
and
since when do you speak english m Dutch?[br][br][size=1]Posted on: July 17, 2009, 04:54:56 am[/size][hr]and why people keep on commenting on silly stuff, gratz you are losing more respect, incase you ran out of it, you can Give people Respects instead to neutralize it.
You people are dirty to a state , where you are totally ready to DDos God with Prayer Flooding , incase you knew what is God etc, but most probably you don’t beleive wich is a happy surprize for you because you are going to Burn in Hell after all the pain you suffer in life, and by arguing with me :))).

Baby all such Suckers Reached the top of my Dick already, while unfortunately , you are still climbing it!
-You Deserve it Because You Started It
Happy Tree Friends.

Read full topic

item.title: Using Reflection?
item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

[quote=“Nader[H.I.M”]link=topic=372894.msg2871201#msg2871201 date=1247774542]
if you are working directly on the client , just get its classloader and reflect fields out of it ,[/quote]
You have a terrible way of talking. If you are working directly on the client (which you most likely aren’t), you can get it’s classloader. Then use loadClass on it to find the required classes. Or you get a bit smarter and get all the loader classes directly from it (useful for reflection explorers)

[quote=“Nader[H.I.M”]link=topic=372894.msg2871201#msg2871201 date=1247774542]
you were trying to use the Loader directly for a cached applet, just get the classLoader of the Canvas field located in the Loader.[/quote]
Get the classloader of the applet field in the loader.

[quote=“Nader[H.I.M”]link=topic=372894.msg2871201#msg2871201 date=1247774542]
Note: get(null) , gets the object incase it was static, else u replace the null by its premitive class.[/quote]
get(null) indeed gets an object in case it was static, otherwise you have to replace ‘null’ by the object from which you want to reflect the field of! Not a primitive class.

Example:
Object client = loader.class.getField(“client”).get(loader);

int static_int = client.class.getField(“whatever”).getInt(null);
int normal_int = client.class.getField(“whatever”).getInt(client);

Read full topic

item.title: Using Reflection?
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

[quote=“BAsh, post:17, topic:282217”][quote author=Tenen link=topic=372894.msg2818748#msg2818748 date=1244440365]
how do i get the instance of the object that i need… or how do i get an instance of an object that some class is using currently.
[/quote]
FAIL. you need to learn some more javas. wld u liek my javas?[/quote]lol. soz, i’m blind sumtimes.

[quote=“unlimitedorb, post:18, topic:282217”]I’m getting tired of threads asking questions only for the answer to be found at the bottom of a long list of spam/non-helpful posts:

Test.java

public class Test {
	private TestSub t;
	
	public Test() {
		t = new TestSub();
	}
	
}

TestSub.java

public class TestSub {
	private int value;
	
	public TestSub() {
		value = 10;
	}
}

ReflectionTest.java

[code]
import java.net.;
import java.lang.reflect.;
import java.io.*;

public class ReflectionTest {
public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception {
ClassLoader loader = new URLClassLoader(new URL[] { new File(“Test.java”).toURI().toURL()});
Class clazz = loader.loadClass(“Test”);
Object client = clazz.newInstance(); //Maps to an instance of the client class in your example.
Field foo = clazz.getDeclaredField(“t”);
foo.setAccessible(true); //Since the field is private we MUST do this.
Object bar = foo.get(client);

	Class clazz2 = bar.getClass();
	Field foo2   = clazz2.getDeclaredField("value");
	foo2.setAccessible(true); //Since the field is private we MUST do this.
	int value    = foo2.getInt(bar);
	System.out.println(value);
}

}
[/code][/quote]LOLOLOL. DUHH, i mean i knew this but i just totally forgot that the object was a field (don’t ask how de ef do i do that). DAMM some1 hack me.

anywayz, thanks for helping

Read full topic

item.title: Using Reflection?
item.dc:creator: @unlimitedorb unlimitedorb
item.description:
@unlimitedorb wrote:

I’m getting tired of threads asking questions only for the answer to be found at the bottom of a long list of spam/non-helpful posts:

Test.java

public class Test {
	private TestSub t;
	
	public Test() {
		t = new TestSub();
	}
	
}

TestSub.java

public class TestSub {
	private int value;
	
	public TestSub() {
		value = 10;
	}
}

ReflectionTest.java

import java.net.*;
import java.lang.reflect.*;
import java.io.*;

public class ReflectionTest {
	public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception {
		ClassLoader loader = new URLClassLoader(new URL[] { new File("Test.java").toURI().toURL()});
		Class clazz = loader.loadClass("Test");
		Object client    =  clazz.newInstance(); //Maps to an instance of the client class in your example.
		Field foo   = clazz.getDeclaredField("t");
		foo.setAccessible(true); //Since the field is private we MUST do this.
		Object bar = foo.get(client);
		
		Class clazz2 = bar.getClass();
		Field foo2   = clazz2.getDeclaredField("value");
		foo2.setAccessible(true); //Since the field is private we MUST do this.
		int value    = foo2.getInt(bar);
		System.out.println(value);
	}
}

Read full topic
